text: okay good morning morning my name is
Erica Hall and I'm an assistant
professor at Emery University and I
wanted to start out by sharing a
personal anecdote so I could tell you
why I started doing research looking at
differing perceptions of the terms
africanamerican and black so I would
often find myself at these cocktail
parties and I would refer to myself as a
black person but I noticed that if my
counterpart was non-black they would
always refer back to me as an
African-American person and so this was
really interesting to me because I
almost felt like oh I self-identified as
a black person I kind of gave you
license to say the word black but still
they would respond by calling me
African-American so I wondered if there
was this certain stigma uh surrounding
the term black that I didn't realize
because I took so much pride in the
world in the word so when we originally
wanted to investigate this question we
started out where all rigorous scholarly
research starts out on
Google and so we initially looked up a
Google image search right and we looked
up black people so if you do image shch
of black people these are the pictures
that you get so take that
in then we looked up African-American
people so we're referring to the same
racial group just a different label
right but we got these
images which are strikingly
different so through our rigorous Google
research and some other really rigorous
uh scholarly research we found that
African-American referred to or
implicitly referred to a higher
socioeconomic status subtype than did
Black and this had consequences for the
positivity or negativity imbued in the
word so first we started out doing a
stereotype content analysis we used the
Princeton Trilogy method which assigns
group one to evaluate a 100 traits on
negativity status uh warmth and
confidence okay and then we have group
two who takes 10 traits out of the 100
that they think are best representative
of blacks whites or
African-Americans
okay and what we found was that the
traits that were assigned to blacks were
higher in negativity and also imbued
less status warmth incompetence than
those assigned to whites or
African-Americans so we were like okay
there must be some societal consequences
what are the consequences for employment
so to say so we were randomly assigned
people to two different groups and we
gave them employee application forms now
these employee application forms were
identical
except for one small
change one said that they listed their
race as black and the other said that
they listed their race as
African-American and then we asked our
participants so what salary do you think
this person should get they thought that
the black person should make a salary of
about
$29,000 but the African-American should
make a salary about
$37,000 significant difference we also
asked them do you think there likely to
be in a managerial
position 38.5% of people thought the
black candidate was likely to be in a
managerial position 73% of people
thought the African-American candidate
was likely to be in a managerial
position so we're like let's move it
into another sphere what about the
consequences for news in the media what
we did was we collected all the crime
reports in five major US uh newspapers
for the years 200 to 2012 then we use
linguistic inquiry word count software
to measure the emotional content which
in E uh within each of those articles
and also the instances or the mentions
of African-American versus
black what we found was that the use of
the term black in a crime report article
was positively correlated with the
negative emotional tone in that article
it was also um negatively correlated
with the positive emotional tone in that
article
okay so that's the media but let's move
on to Criminal Justice right because it
could have uh consequences here so you
know particularly if you're at an
academic institution those news blasts
that you get where it says a black
suspect was seen running on Lake Street
near the dorm after committing some
crime right so we sent out these news
blast but the suspect was either a black
suspect or an African-American suspect
and what we found was that when the
person was an African-American suspect
participants had more warmth they were
more warm to that suspect than whether
it was a black
suspect so oh right in time
okay so I rushed through this a little
bit there are more details that I would
have liked to have covered but if you're
interested you can look at the paper or
ask me any questions thank you very
much
